content.question:
<math alttext="A g C l solid is in equilibrium with A g with a positive 1 charge aqueous plus C l with a negative 1 charge aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AgCl</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

When <math alttext="A g C l solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AgCl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is placed in water, it dissolves according to the chemical equation above. The particle diagram above was proposed to represent an aqueous solution in which <math alttext="A g C l solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AgCl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is in equilibrium with its ions. Which of the following best explains whether or not the diagram provides a good representation of this dynamic equilibrium at the microscopic level?

choices.label: It is a good representation because it shows that the dipoles of the <math alttext="H 2 O" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules are oriented around the <math alttext="A g with a positive 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C l with a negative 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions in solution.

It is a good representation because it shows that the concentrations of <math alttext="A g with a positive 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions and <math alttext="C l with a negative 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions are equal at equilibrium.

It is not a good representation because it does not show that the concentration of <math alttext="A g C l solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AgCl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is constant at equilibrium.
It is not a good representation because it does not illustrate the dynamic equilibrium in which the rates of the forward and reverse reactions are equal.

content.answer: It is not a good representation because it does not illustrate the dynamic equilibrium in which the rates of the forward and reverse reactions are equal.

skill.text: 4.D: Explain the degree to which a model or representation describes the connection between particulate-level properties and macroscopic properties.
